ЁЯЧ║я╕П
Geography and Capital

The Chera dynasty was one of the three major crowned kings (Muvendrar) of ancient Tamilakam. Their rule was primarily over modern Kerala and western Tamil Nadu (Kongu Nadu). Their capital was Vanji (near modern Karur or Kodungallur), and their major ports were Muziris (Muchiri) and Tondi, which were centers of international trade.

ЁЯЪв
Trade and Economy

The Cheras were renowned for their maritime power and extensive spice trade with the Roman Empire. Muziris was called 'India's First Emporium'. Black pepper (Yavanpriya), pearls, and ivory were exported from here, and in return, Roman gold and wine were imported. Sangam literature, especially 'Padirruppattu', narrates the valor and prosperity of the Chera kings.

ЁЯП╣
Symbol and Culture

Their royal emblem was the 'bow and arrow', symbolizing their martial prowess. The Chera kings patronized the Tamil language and Sangam poets. According to the epic Silappathikaram, King Senguttuvan established the Pattini cult in honor of 'Kannagi'.
